instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I’m new to the forum but have some limited experience with simple MacBook logic board repairs.

I’m working on a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) that presented with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. No obvious liquid exposure. I removed F7000, injected 2 V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, which heated up the CPU power MOSFET <TRANSISTOR>Q7960</TRANSISTOR>. I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7960</TRANSISTOR> and localized the short to <SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0G</SIGNAL> (< 1 Ω). I tried injecting 1.2 V at <SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0G</SIGNAL>, but nothing seems to get warm after a few minutes (10 A power supply). How can I definitively say the CPU is shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> can be damaged too.
Lift L7960 and check where the short remains.

Do NOT inject again in the same manner.
You MUST discard first a shorted high-side MOSFET from secondary power supplies.
We talked about this so many times on the forum.
Even 2V could damage the CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you. After lifting L7960 I get a 0.2 Ohm short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0G</SIGNAL>. Notably, I also get 1 Ohm short on <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL>. Safe to assume that this CPU is toast?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 0.2 ohm means shorted CPU for sure...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: For next time, what's the resistance to ground I should expect for these CPU/PCH power rails (<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0G</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>, etc)? Are these all low-resistance (<100 Ohm) power rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with shorted <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Take notes from repaired boards.
Is the safest way to make your personal database.
Powerfull CPUs have very low values, 1-2 ohm...
